text: When I have read his stuff first time many years ago, I refused to agree with him on most points and was blaming him for not trying hard enough to understand OOP philosophy.
However while still being object-happy programmer, always when I felt sort of frustrated by OOP, I landed on his website to understand better why.
He might not be the best writer in the world but definitely someone who deserves attention.
Although the GOF book is a "must-read", some patterns are not very useful when coding in a flexible language like Python.
I believe the best you can do to "get" OOP is not to read a book, but try to design something "Object Intensive" like a small game, trying to do without 3rd party libraries as much as possible.
Good Luck!
